page.title: 1.14.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will review proportions and proportional relationships. Understanding proportions will help you learn how to recognize direct variation situations. You will then set up direct variation equations and work to solve problems. Direct variation is seen in everyday life in a variety of proportional relationships. Examples include the amount a paycheck increases with more hours of work; the distance a car travels compared to its rate of speed; and the cost of an electric bill based on the amount of electricity used. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Set up and solve direct variation problems.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.14.1: Solving Proportions
  • 1.14.2: Modeling Equations Using Direct Variation
  • 1.14.2: Self Check 
  • 1.14.3: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 1
  • 1.14.3: Self Check 
  • 1.14.4: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 2

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.14.5: Practice
  • 1.14.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.14.1: Solving Proportions
page.contents:
Warm-Up Activity

Solve each of the following proportions:

1. \( \frac{x}{56} = \frac{7}{8} \)

Cross multiply. \( 8x = 7(56) \)
Simplify. \( 8x = 392 \)
Divide both sides by 8. \( \frac{8x}{8}=\frac{392}{8} \)
Simplify. \( x=49 \)


2. \( \frac{56}{72} = \frac{y}{9} \)

Cross multiply. \( 56(9)=72y \)
Simplify. \( 504 =72y \)
Divide both sides by 72. \( \frac{504}{72}=\frac{72y}{72} \)
Simplify. \( x=7 \)


3. \( \frac{98}{134} = \frac{-7}{p} \)

Cross multiply. \( 98p= -7(154) \)
Simplify. \( 98p = -1078 \)
Divide both sides by 98. \( \frac{98p}{98}=\frac{-1078}{98} \)
Simplify. \( p = -11 \)

page.title: 1.14.2: Modeling Equations Using Direct Variation
page.contents:
Activity

In your group, work through your assigned problem. Then be ready to share. 

Group 1. When Raoul uses the treadmill at the gym, the number of calories, \( c \), he burns varies directly with the number of minutes, \( m \), he uses the treadmill. He burned 315 calories when he used the treadmill for 18 minutes. Write the equation that relates \( c \) and \( m \). 

Group 2. The number of calories, \( c \), burned varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. Write the equation that relates \( c \) and \( t \).

Group 3. The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours. Write the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer: 

Group 1: \( c=17.5m \)
Group 2: \( c = 4.8 m \)
Group 3: \( d= 50t \)


What Is Direct Variation?

All of these are examples of direct variation.

Two variables vary directly if one is the product of a constant and the other.

For any two variables \( x \) and \( y \), \( y \) varies directly with \( x \) if 

\( y=kx \), where \( k≠0 \).

The constant \(k\) is called the constant of variation.

Look back at the problem you solved. Use the direct variation equation to solve it again using these steps:

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 4

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.


Let’s look at example 3 again and solve it with the direct variation equation.

The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours. Write the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \).

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 100 = k(2) \)

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k=50 \)

Step 4

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.

\( y =50x \)

page.title: 1.14.2: Self Check
page.contents: The price, \( P \), that Eric pays for gas varies directly with the number of gallons, \( g \), he buys. It costs him $65 to buy 25 gallons of gas. Which equation expresses the price of any amount of gas, \( P \), in terms of the number of gallons, \( g \)?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself: 

Use the direct variation equation, \( y=kx \). 

Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). 

Now, \( k=\frac{65}{25}=\frac{13}{5} \). 

So, the equation is \( P=\frac{13}{5}g \).

Incorrect. This is the equation if each gallon was $25. Let’s try again a different way:

Use the direct variation equation, \( y=kx \). 

Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k=\frac{65}{25}=\frac{13}{5} \). 

The answer is \( P=\frac{13}{5}g \).

Incorrect. This is the equation if Eric wants to find the cost per a certain number of gallons that is not known. Let’s try again a different way:

Use the direct variation equation, \( y=kx \). 

Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k=\frac{65}{25}=\frac{13}{5} \). 

The answer is \( P=\frac{13}{5}g \).

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: 

Make sure that you solve for \(k\) correctly.  Use the direct variation equation, \( y=kx \). 

Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k=\frac{65}{25}=\frac{13}{5} \). 

The answer is \( P=\frac{13}{5}g \).

page.title: 1.14.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Modeling Situations Using Direct Variation 

When two quantities are related by a proportion, we say they are proportional to each other. Another way to express this relation is to talk about the variation of the two quantities. We will discuss direct variation here.

Lindsay gets paid $15 per hour at her job. If we let \( s \) be her salary, in dollars per hour, and \( h \) be the number of hours she has worked, we could model this situation with the equation

\( s=15h \).

Lindsay’s salary is the product of a constant, 15, and the number of hours she works. We say that Lindsay’s salary varies directly with the number of hours she works. Two variables vary directly if one is the product of a constant and the other.

Direct Variation

For any two variables \( x \) and \( y \), \( y \) varies directly with \( x \) if


\( y=kx \), where \( k≠0 \).

The constant \(k\) is called the constant of variation.

In applications using direct variation, we will generally know values of one pair of the variables and will be asked to find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \). 

Recall how to model an equation using direct variation for application problems:

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 4

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.


Let’s look at an application problem:

The cost of a pizza, \( y \), varies directly with its diameter, \( x \), and an 8-inch pizza costs $12. What is the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \)?

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 12 = k(8) \)

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k=\frac{12}{8}=\frac{3}{2} \)

Step 4

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.

\( y=\frac{3}{2}x \)


Try It: Modeling Situations Using Direct Variation

The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 60 miles in 2 hours.
What is the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \)? 

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.


Here is how to model this application problem using direct variation:

Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)
\( d=kt \)

Step 2

Identify the variables

\( d \): distance, \( t \): time

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 60 = k(2) \)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation, \(k\).

\( k=30 \)

Step 5

Write the equation that relates \(d\) and \(t\) using the constant of variation.

\( d=30t \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.14.3: Self Check
page.contents: Sophia is making parts for a model ship. The number of parts, \( p \), she can make in a day varies directly with the number of hours, \( h \), she works. She can make 28 parts in 4 hours. How many parts would Sophia make in 9 hours?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The constant of variation is \( \frac{28}{4}=7 \). 

The equation is now \( p=7h \). After 9 hours, Sophia makes 63 parts.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to use multiplication in direct variation. 

The constant of variation is \( \frac{28}{4}=7 \). 

The equation is now \( p=7h \). After 9 hours, Sophia makes 63 parts.

The answer is 63 parts.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Recall how to use parentheses when multiplying. 

The constant of variation is \( \frac{28}{4}=7 \). 

The equation is now \( p=7h \). After 9 hours, Sophia makes 63 parts.

The answer is 63 parts.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to find the constant of variation before substituting into the equation. 

The constant of variation is \( \frac{28}{4}=7 \). 

The equation is now \( p=7h \). After 9 hours, Sophia makes 63 parts.

The answer is 63 parts.

page.title: 1.14.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. If y varies directly as x and y=14, when x=3. find the equation that relates x and y.

Correct! \(y=\frac{14}3x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.14.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=\frac{14}3x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. The price, P, that Eric pays for gas varies directly with the number of gallons, g, he buys. It costs him $50 to buy 20 gallons of gas.
Choose the equation that relates P and g.

Correct! \(P = 2.5g\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(P = 2.5g\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. Joseph is traveling on a road trip. The distance, d, he travels before stopping for lunch varies directly with the speed, v, he travels. He can travel 120 miles at a speed of 60 mph. How many miles would he travel before stopping for lunch at a rate of 65 mph? Only enter integers.

Correct! 130 miles

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 130 miles. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. The mass of a liquid, M, varies directly with its volume, V. A liquid with mass 16 kilograms has a volume of 2 liters. What is the volume, in liters, of this liquid if its mass is 128 kilograms? Enter integers only.

Correct! 16 liters. \(M=8V\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 16 liters. \(M=8V\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. The length, L, that a spring stretches varies directly with a weight, W, placed at the end of the spring. When Sarah placed a 10-pound watermelon on a hanging scale, the spring stretched 5 inches. What weight of watermelon, in pounds, would stretch the spring 6 inches? Enter integers only.

Correct! 12 pounds, \(L=1/2 W\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 12 pounds, \(L=\frac12W\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. The maximum load a beam, M, will support varies directly with the square of the diagonal of the beam’s cross-section, \(d^2\). A beam with diagonal 6 inch will support a maximum load of 108 pounds. What load, in pounds, will a beam with a 10-inch diagonal support? Enter integers only.

Correct! 300 pounds. Use the direct variation equation, \(M=3d^2\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 300 pounds. Use the direct variation equation, \(M=3d^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. The number of calories, c, burned varies directly with the amount of time, t, spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. How many calories would he burn if he exercises for 90 minutes? Enter integers only.

Correct! He would burn 432 calories.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 1.14.2 and 1.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is is a. \(M\)\(=8V\); b. 16 liters. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.14.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solve Application Problems Using Direct Variation

In applications using direct variation, we will generally know values of one pair of the variables and will be asked to find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \). Then we can use that equation to find values of \( y \) for other values of \( x \).

Recall how to model an equation using direct variation for application problems:

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

Step 2

Identify the variables.

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 5

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.

Step 6

Substitute the value for the variable.

Step 7

Solve.


Let’s look at an application problem:

If the cost of a pizza varies directly with its diameter, and an 8-inch pizza costs $12, how much would a 6-inch pizza cost?

Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Identify the variables.

\( y \): cost of pizza;
\( x \): diameter

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 12 = k(8) \)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k=\frac{12}{8}=\frac{3}{2} \)

Step 4

Write the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \) using the constant of variation.

\( y=\frac{3}{2}x \)

Step 4

Substitute the value for the variable.

\( y=\frac{3}{2}(6) \)

Step 4

Solve.

\( y = 9  \)


What does this mean in the context of the problem?

A pizza that has a diameter of 6 inches costs $9.


Try It: Solve Application Problems Using Direct Variation

The number of buckets of water, \(b\), filled by a spring varies directly with the number of minutes, \(m\), that have passed. The spring fills 3 buckets of water in 14 minutes.

How many buckets would be filled in 42 minutes?

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.


Here is how to model this application problem of direct variation:

Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)
\( b=km \)

Step 2

Identify the variables.

\( b \): number of buckets;
\( m \): number of minutes

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 3=k(14) \)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k= \frac{3}{14} \)

Step 5

Write the equation that relates \( m \) and \( b \) using the constant of variation.

\( b=\frac{3}{14}m \)

Step 6

Substitute the value for the variable.

\( b=\frac{3}{14}(42) \)

Step 7

Solve.

\( b= 9  \) buckets

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.14.3: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 1
page.contents:
Activity

Return to your original group and work through this next part of your assigned problem. Then be ready to share. 

Group 1. When Raoul uses the treadmill at the gym, the number of calories, \( c \), he burns varies directly with the number of minutes, \( m \), he uses the treadmill. He burned 315 calories when he used the treadmill for 18 minutes. 

How many calories would he burn if he uses the treadmill for 25 minutes?

2. The number of calories, \( c \), burned varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. 

How many calories would he burn if he exercises for 90 minutes?

3. The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours. 

How many miles would it travel in 5 hours?

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer: 

Group 1: \( c=437.5 \), so Raoul would burn 437.5 calories if he used the treadmill for 25 minutes.
Group 2: \( c=432 \)
Group 3: 250 miles


Video: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems

Watch the following video to learn more about how to use direct variation to solve an application problem.

    


Extending Your Thinking

For example 1, how could you find out how many minutes Raoul would need to use the treadmill to burn a certain number of calories?

Write your answer here:

Sample response: Substitute the number of calories you want to burn into the equation for \( c \) and then solve for \( t \).

page.title: 1.14.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Set up and solve direct variation problems.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.14.1: Solving Proportions 
    • In this activity, you recalled how to solve proportions for variables.
  • 1.14.2: Modeling Equations Using Direct Variation
    • In this activity, you found the constant of variation given a situation and wrote a direct variation equation.
  • 1.14.2: Self Check 
  • 1.14.3: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 1
    • In this activity, you continued to find the constant of variation and write direct variation equations. In addition, you solved the equations for a given constraint in application problems.
  • 1.14.3: Self Check 
  • 1.14.4: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 2
    • In this activity, you looked at a direct variation situation involving the miles a car can travel given the gallons of gas and distance. 
After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.14.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 1.14.4: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 2
page.contents:
Cool-Down Activity

Jesse’s car gets 30 miles per gallon of gas.

1. Write an equation using direct variation for distance, \( d \), and number of gallons of gas, \( g \), for this problem.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

Use the equation for direct variation \( y=kx \). So, \( d=kg \).


2. If Jesse travels 150 miles, he uses 5 gallons of gas. Find the constant of variation.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

Use the equation for direct variation \( y=kx \). So, \( 150=k(5) \). The constant of variation is \( k=30 \).


3. Now, write the equation if Jesse travels \( d \) miles with a car that gets 30 miles per gallon of gas.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( d=30g \)


4. If Las Vegas is 285 miles away, how many gallons of gas are needed to get there?

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

Substitute 285 miles in for \( m \) in the equation. So, \( d=30(285)=8,550 \).
